Comments_List: Really the course's strong suit was to get me thinking about particular topics, rather than specifically instruct anything in particular. I will say there were a few sessions that stressed the gravity of our responsibility in ways that stuck with me.
I learned about several topics on academic ethics and received instructions on how to develop a successful academic career.
Learned how to stay integrity during conducting research or writing a paper.
Learned about mentoring, science communication, fraud, intellectual property, scientific writing.

All the guest lecture folk were quite good, but not all of their talks were. Some were too long and some had borrowed slides for which they knew not the point. But generally, much better than expected for this sort of course.
Lecturers were engaged and interested. Material was broad and interesting. Great!

There should be a clearer outline of the absence policy, and I think allowing students to miss one class and make it up by writing a summary would be more fair than requiring the class be repeated. Also mentors and papers should be assigned based on the interests of the student in order for us to get the most out of this.
I think that it was okay. I get that it was a mandated course, so like it isn't necessarily the most engaging, but I think for what it was, it was the best it could be.
This isn't really a course that can be recommended in the way I think this question thinks it is.
Yes, because there is some knowledge that I didn't know before taking this course.
Compulsory, so ... eh. But it was good!
